text.content:
This page explains attacks and all weapons in the 5e ruleset. We have made some changes to weapon properties for balance purposes. See @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-rules.JournalEntry.VLxJ80DY7q7hkXU7.JournalEntryPage.lGSbEoSpNvTEN1Dy]{here} for a complete breakdown.



The various weapon properties are listed below:

  • &reference[Adamantine]

  • &reference[cold iron]

  • &reference[Ammunition]

  • &reference[Finesse]

  • &reference[Heavy]

  • &reference[light weapon]

  • &reference[Loading]

  • &reference[magic weapon]

  • &reference[Mounted]

  • &reference[Reach]

  • &reference[Thrown]

  • &reference[Handed]

  • &reference[Silver]

  • &reference[Unwieldy]

  • &reference[Versatile]

Adamantine is a magical material harder and harder to break than any nonmagical metal. It can cut materials like steel and stone without a scratch. Most golems are resistant or immune to non-adamantine weapons. Magic weapons can damage these creatures, but not as effectively as adamantine weapons.

Cold iron is not a magical material itself, but creating it usually involves the use of magic. Unlike steel or the iron used in most conventional products, cold iron is pure from both chemical and magical impurities through a rigorous process that requires specific equipment and training. Most &reference[fey] are resistant or immune to non-cold iron weapons. Cold iron weapons can also be used against incorporeal &reference[undead] (though magic weapons also work).

You can use a weapon that has the Ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have Ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. You need an empty hand to load a one-handed ranged weapon.


We STRONGLY suggest that if a character has at least 20 pieces of ammunition, they can stop tracking ammunition. You can recover ammunition after using it. You should always purchase or find standard ammunition types in quantities of 20.

Silver can harm and burn many supernatural creatures where conventional weapons do not. Many &reference[celestial]{Celestials}, &reference[fiend]{Fiends}, lycanthropes, and some &reference[undead] (including vampires) are resistant to non-silver weapons.
When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage Rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.
A Light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two Weapons. A weapon that is not Light cannot normally be used in the off-hand of a dual-wielding character.
Because of the time required to load this weapon, when you use the &reference[Attack] action to attack with a loading weapon, you must also use a bonus action to load the weapon.

Some weapons are enchanted. These weapons are unique and not listed on this page, but a 'magic' weapon is any weapon that has a bonus to attack and damage rolls, or which is otherwise designated as a 'magic' weapon of uncommon rarity or higher.


Magical weapons deal magical &reference[bludgeoning], &reference[piercing], or &reference[slashing] damage. Some creatures are resistant or immune to damage from weapons that are nonmagical. A mud golem, for instance, can only be easily cut by magic weapons.
This weapon is meant to be used while mounted. This weapon is considered &reference[Handed] when not mounted, but can be held in one hand when mounted.

This weapon has a longer reach when you attack with it, whether on your turn or for determining your reach for @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-rules.JournalEntry.C3b7Ref9xEVn34Gf.JournalEntryPage.5zEWVU1yw2Sv3hSI]{Attacks of Opportunity}. The reach is listed in parentheses.
If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. You must then retrieve the weapon from where it landed to throw it again.
This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it. You may still use one of your hands to load a weapon or cast a spell while holding a Two-handed weapon.
This weapon is unsuited for combat in close quarters, and is meant for attacks at extended range. You have disadvantage on attacks against creatures within 5 ft. of you.
This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage die in parentheses appears with the versatile property - the damage die when the weapon is used with two hands.

Below is an explanation of all the characteristics that go into a weapon.


Melee weapons are weapons that can be used to attack effectively at close range. Most melee weapons can only be used to attack creatures that are within 5 ft. of you. Melee weapons with the Thrown property can also be used as a ranged weapon.


Ranged weapons are weapons meant to attack at a longer range. If any hostile creature is within 5 ft., you have disadvantage on any attack roll with a Ranged weapon or when making a ranged attack with a Thrown weapon. Range is explained below.


Where the Damage of a given weapon type is listed, a weapon damage die will be provided, the relevant ability modifier(s) for damage will be listed. 'str' means strength modifier, 'dex' means dexterity modifier, and 'str/dex' means you choose strength or dexterity, whichever is higher, as per the &reference[Finesse] property.


A weapon's Damage Type describes the way in which a weapon deals damage to the target. Bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing represent whether the weapon uses blunt force, stabbing, or cutting to injure a creature. Some creatures will be vulnerable, resistant, or immune to certain damage types. If a weapon has more than one damage type listed, you can use either damage type when you hit with the weapon.


The Range for ranged and thrown weapons lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's long range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range. If you have disadvantage on your attack roll from something other than shooting at long range, then you can only target a creature within the normal range, not the long range.


The weapon's cost is the weapon's normal cost when sold at a good price. Some regions or merchants may charge more than this value.


@embed[.0mJgDHc69dAZQtRr inline]

Prices for magic, adamantine, cold iron, and silver weapons (and all combinations of the above) are listed on individual items. If you want a quick reference of all weapon prices, you can visit the weapons page on our website.

This property has no effects on its own, but may be referenced by other abilities. Click @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-rules.JournalEntry.VLxJ80DY7q7hkXU7.JournalEntryPage.lGSbEoSpNvTEN1Dy]{here} for more information.

A concussive weapon fires bullets that both &reference[piercing]{pierce} foes and &reference[bludgeoning]{bludgeoning} them on impact. Whenever a concussive weapon deals damage, it deals either bludgeoning or piercing damage, whichever is more advantageous.
